benchmark_details.name: Potential Idiomatic Expression (PIE)-English
benchmark_details.overview: We present a fairly large, Potential Idiomatic Expression (PIE) dataset for Natural Language Processing (NLP) in English, containing over 20,100 samples with almost 1,200 cases of idioms classified into 10 different classes.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The primary objective of this work is to create a high-quality corpus of potential idiomatic expressions in the English language and make it publicly available for NLP researchers.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: A limitation of the PIE-English dataset, which seems inevitable, is the dominance of metaphors, since metaphors are the most common figures of speech.

data.source: British National Corpus (BNC) and UK Web Pages (UKWaC)
data.annotation: Annotated by two independent annotators with an overall inter-annotator agreement (IAA) score of 88.89%.

methodology.calculation: Accuracy and F1 Score were calculated for each class and overall across the dataset.
methodology.interpretation: Good results are obtained when classifying idioms, especially using BERT which outperformed other classifiers.
methodology.baseline_results: BERT: Accuracy 0.934, F1 Score 0.948; SVM: Accuracy 0.766, F1 Score 0.67; mNB: Accuracy 0.747, F1 Score 0.66.
methodology.validation: Stratified data-split for training and validation sets was done to address the class imbalance.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Contributors are predominantly L2 English speakers, but detailed demographic analysis beyond this is not specified.
